questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Lamentations 1:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'how' and the emotional tone of lament.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'how' (how lonely, how like a widow, how she weeps) to emphasize the depth of sorrow
Pay attention to the phrase 'she who was great among the nations' (v.3) to contrast her former glory with current state
The emotional tone shifts from lament to a plea for divine justice (v.12-14)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jerusalem) is affected, WHAT (the city's desolation), WHERE (exile among nations), and WHY (rebellion against God) in Lamentations 1.
tips: Jerusalem as a city that was once powerful but now is a widow in exile
The city's weeping and the abandonment by its former allies
The cause: Judah's rebellion against God (v.12-14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the city's weeping (v.1-2), the comparison to a widow (v.3), or the cry for divine justice (v.12-14)?
tips: The phrase 'how lonely sits the city that was full of people' (v.1) captures the profound isolation and loss of identity
The image of Jerusalem as a widow (v.3) is powerful because it shows the loss of her former status and the emotional pain of abandonment
The plea 'Is it nothing to you, all you who pass by?' (v.12) is a direct cry for attention from the divine

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to exilic Judah through this passage?
tips: Jeremiah is calling Judah to recognize the LORD's righteous judgment on their rebellion (v.12-14) and to lament the consequences of their sin
This passage emphasizes that God's justice is real and that Jerusalem's desolation is a result of their own actions
The theme of God's righteousness (v.14) is central to Jeremiah's message: God is in the right and Judah has rebelled against His word

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The city being a widow? The phrase 'LORD is in the right'? The comparison to a widow in ancient context?
tips: In ancient Near Eastern culture, a widow was a woman without a husband, often with no inheritance and social standing. Here, Jerusalem is a 'widow' because she has lost her husband (the people of God)
The phrase 'LORD is in the right' (v.14) is a strong declaration of God's justice, which might be challenging because it emphasizes God's judgment rather than grace

The term 'exile' in this context is a specific historical event where the people of Judah were taken away from their land by Babylon, but the passage uses the metaphor of a widow to show the city's lo

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the theme of Jerusalem weeping (as a widow) apply to your current situation? What can you do this week to become a comforter for someone who is grieving?
tips: Consider a friend or family member who is going through a difficult time and offer to be a 'comforter' like the city needed
Practice active listening and validation when someone is grieving, as Jerusalem was weeping without comfort
Reflect on how you can be the 'princess' (v.3) who brings hope and restoration to others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: For the city of Jerusalem (as a symbol of our spiritual state) to find comfort in God's righteousness, and for us to be a source of hope in times of desolation.
tips: Thank God for His justice and for being the righteous judge who does not forget His people
Ask for the strength to be a comforter to those who are grieving
Pray that God would restore the brokenness of Jerusalem and help us to become the 'princess' who brings hope

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Lamentations 2:1-22 aloud, focusing on the emotional tone of the lament and the repeated phrase 'The LORD's anger'.
tips: Notice the phrase 'The LORD's anger' appears in the opening line (v.1) and is a recurring theme throughout the chapter
Pay attention to the vivid imagery: 'gates sunk into the ground' (v.12), 'burned like a flaming fire' (v.19), and 'stomach churns' (v.18)
The emotional tone shifts from accusation to despair, with a focus on the people's helplessness

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (the LORD) is doing WHAT (destroying Judah) WHERE (the city of Jerusalem) and WHY (due to the people's sin and unfaithfulness).
tips: Include the destruction of Jerusalem: gates sunk, strongholds broken
Note the role of false prophets who provide deceptive visions
The context is the exile of Judah after the fall of Jerusalem

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the imagery of 'gates sunk into the ground' (v.12), the silence of the elders (v.15), or the physical and emotional suffering of the people (v.18).
tips: 'Her gates have sunk into the ground' (v.12) vividly portrays the complete destruction of Jerusalem, leaving nothing but ruins
The elders sitting in silence (v.15) shows the profound spiritual desolation and the absence of leadership
'My eyes are spent with weeping; my stomach churns' (v.18) expresses the deep emotional and physical toll of the exile

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to exilic Judah through Lamentations 2? How does this passage reflect God's relationship with His people in their time of exile?
tips: Jeremiah is lamenting the destruction of Jerusalem and the exile, showing that God's wrath has fallen on Judah due to their sin
The passage also points to the need for repentance and the hope of future restoration through Christ
This chapter emphasizes God's justice but also His covenant love that will one day be restored

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The phrase 'He has not remembered His footstool in the day of His anger' (v.4), the concept of 'swallowed up without mercy' (v.10), and the role of false prophets (v.18).
tips: 'Footstool' refers to God's stable and unshakable presence; here, God 'forgets' this in His wrath, indicating a temporary absence of His presence
'Swallowed up without mercy' means God has destroyed Judah completely without showing compassion, which is a sign of His righteous judgment
False prophets (v.18) are those who provided visions that were not from God, leading to confusion and the people's suffering

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'weeping witness' (Lamentations 2:18) to your life this week? In what way are you expressing your pain and hope for restoration?
tips: Identify one area where you feel God's anger has been real (e.g., broken relationships, personal struggles)
Pray for the comfort of God's mercy and for the hope of restoration, just as the exiles hoped for
Write down one thing you can share with others that reflects your weeping for the brokenness of the world

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His mercy and ask for the strength to endure in the midst of suffering, just as the exiles did. Also, pray for the coming of the day of restoration.
tips: Thank God for His promise of future restoration through Christ
Ask for the courage to face the pain of the present while holding hope in His mercy
Pray for the exiles' lament to be a reminder of the need for repentance and faith

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Lamentations 3:1-28 aloud, focusing on the contrast between despair (vv.1-10) and hope (vv.11-28).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'He has' in verses 1-10 to emphasize God's actions
Pay attention to the shift from 'I am the man' (v.1) to 'The LORD is my portion' (v.17)
The phrase 'mercies new every morning' (v.19) carries deep hope

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is suffering, WHAT God has done, WHERE and WHEN this occurs, and WHY Jeremiah writes this.
tips: The affliction described in verses 1-10 (e.g., being driven into darkness, bones broken)
The shift in verses 11-17 to God's steadfast love and mercy
The call to return to God in verses 18-28

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of affliction (vv.1-10), the hope in God's mercy (vv.11-17), or the call to return (vv.18-28)?
tips: The phrase 'The LORD is my portion, says my soul, therefore I will hope in Him' (v.17) - this is a profound declaration of identity and hope
The repetition of 'mercies new every morning' (v.19) - it emphasizes God's ongoing provision
The call to 'test and examine our ways' (v.21) - practical hope in action

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to exilic Judah through this passage?
tips: To remind exiles that even in the deepest suffering, God's mercy is unending and new each day
To encourage persistence in hope despite current trials
To show that God's faithfulness is the foundation for hope in the future

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The depth of suffering described, the meaning of 'mercies new every morning', or the call to return?
tips: 'He has made my flesh and my skin waste away' (v.3) - a vivid description of physical and spiritual decay in exile
'Mercies new every morning' (v.19) - refers to God's constant renewal of mercy, not just a single gift
The phrase 'the LORD is my portion' (v.17) - this is a declaration of identity that shifts from despair to hope

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of hope in God's mercy and what action you can take this week.
tips: Identify one area where you feel overwhelmed and ask God for His new mercy each morning
Pray for the strength to 'test and examine your ways' (v.21) by reflecting on your actions this week
Write down one thing you can do to 'return to the LORD' (v.21) this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about hope in God's mercy during affliction.
tips: Thank God for His unending mercy even when you feel abandoned
Ask for the courage to trust Him as your portion (v.17) in your current struggles
Pray for the strength to 'lift up your hearts and hands' (v.21) to Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Lamentations 4:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of despair and the vivid imagery of the siege.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'how' (how the gold has grown dim, how the pure gold is changed)
Emphasize the contrast between past glory and present desolation
Note the phrase 'the tongue of the nursing infant sticks to the roof of its mouth' for its visceral impact

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is suffering, WHAT is happening, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters in the context of the siege.
tips: Include the contrast between the past (princes pure as snow) and present (faces blacker than soot)
Mention the children starving and mothers boiling their children
Note the comparison to Sodom as the ultimate measure of punishment

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of children starving (v. 5-6), the comparison to Sodom (v. 12), or the image of mothers boiling their children (v. 10)?
tips: The children's plea for food without being given (v. 5) shows the depth of desperation
The comparison to Sodom (v. 12) emphasizes the extreme nature of the punishment
The image of mothers boiling their children (v. 10) is a shocking act of maternal desperation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to exilic Judah about the consequences of their sin and the need for God's mercy?
tips: The passage shows the total devastation of sin on the community
Jeremiah is lamenting the complete breakdown of the city and its people
This is a call for the exiles to remember God's faithfulness and the need for repentance

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The image of mothers boiling their children, why the punishment is worse than Sodom, and the meaning of 'the tongue sticks to the roof of the mouth'?
tips: The phrase 'boiling their own children' (v. 10) is a metaphor for extreme desperation, not literal boiling
Sodom was destroyed by God's wrath (Genesis 19), but here the punishment is even worse because it's a community of God's people
The tongue sticking to the roof of the mouth (v. 5) is a sign of extreme thirst and dehydration

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the suffering of the children in this passage to your own life? What does it mean to be a protector of the vulnerable?
tips: Consider how you can provide for those who are hungry or in need this week
Think about being a safe place for others who are suffering
Practice compassion by reaching out to children or the elderly in your community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the suffering of the children and the hope of restoration in the context of this siege.
tips: Ask God for mercy for the exiles and the city of Jerusalem
Pray for the protection of the vulnerable, especially children
Thank God that He is the one who will restore the broken city

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Lamentations 5:1-14 aloud, focusing on the emotional tone of despair and the repeated plea for restoration.
tips: Notice the phrase 'We have become orphans, fatherless' in verse 1
Pay attention to the repetition of 'We' and the collective suffering in verses 2-5
Notice the shift from lamentation to hope in verses 6-14

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is suffering, WHAT they are praying for, WHERE they are located, and WHY they are in this state.
tips: Include the exiles in Babylon as the 'we'
Note that they are praying for God to restore their land and identity
Mention the sin of their ancestors and the current suffering

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the plea for restoration (v.14), the cry for God's memory (v.5), or the phrase 'We have become orphans' (v.1)?
tips: The phrase 'We have become orphans, fatherless' (v.1) vividly captures the loss of identity and family
The line 'We get our bread at the peril of our lives' (v.3) shows the extreme hardship and danger of survival
The declaration 'But You, O LORD, reign forever' (v.6) offers a contrast of divine permanence amid human suffering

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah trying to communicate to exilic Judah through this passage?
tips: The passage is a prayer for God to remember and restore the exiles from their current state of ruin
Jeremiah emphasizes that the suffering is due to their ancestors' sins but God's eternal reign provides hope for restoration
The prayer calls for God to act in the midst of exile, not just in the past

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'we have become orphans, fatherless' (v.1), the reference to 'princes hung up' (v.7), or the concept of 'bearing fathers' sins (v.5)?
tips: 'Orphans, fatherless' refers to the loss of the temple and kingdom, not literal children
The phrase 'princes hung up by their hands' describes the political oppression of the Babylonian rulers
'Bearing fathers' sins' means the exiles are inheriting the consequences of their ancestors' disobedience

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'we must pay for the water we drink' (v.1) to your current life?
tips: When facing financial struggles, remember that God is the provider and trust Him to meet your needs
Consider an area where you are holding back from full trust in God's provision
Pray for the grace to be a 'living sacrifice' as the exiles were in their suffering

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Ask God to restore us to You, as we have sinned and are in exile.
tips: Thank God for His eternal reign and provision through Christ
Pray for courage to trust in His restoration despite current suffering
Ask for the strength to bear the weight of our sins and to find hope in Him
